statements: UPDATE table1 SET source1_data = 'NewValue1' WHERE id = 1
UPDATE table1 SET source2_data = 'NewValue2' WHERE id = 2
UPDATE table1 SET source1_data = 'value1', source2_data = 'value2' WHERE id = 1;
UPDATE table1 SET source2_data = 'value3', source1_data = 'value4' WHERE id = 2;
UPDATE Table1 SET column1 = 10, column2 = 'Updated Value' WHERE column3 = '2022-01-01 10:00:00'
UPDATE Table2 SET column5 = 'New Value', column4 = 5 WHERE column6 = 100.50
UPDATE Table1 SET column2 = 'Updated Value 1' WHERE column1 = 1;
UPDATE Table2 SET column6 = 25.75, column5 = 'New Text Value';
UPDATE table1 SET column2 = 'New Value' WHERE column1 = 1;
UPDATE table2 SET column6 = 1000.50, column5 = 'Updated Value' WHERE column4 = 10;
UPDATE table1 SET column2 = 'New Value' WHERE column1 = 1;
UPDATE table3 SET column8 = 'Updated Value', column7 = 5 WHERE column9 = 10.5;

UPDATE table3 SET column5 = true, column4 = 'Updated' WHERE column4 = 'Original Value';

UPDATE table3 SET column5 = true WHERE column4 = 'value2';
UPDATE customers SET email = 'newemail@example.com' WHERE customer_id = 1
UPDATE orders SET total_amount = 500.00 WHERE order_id = 100
UPDATE customers SET phone='+1234567890', email='john.doe@example.com' WHERE customer_id=1
